bibl.title: Letter from Manuel Avila to Joseph H. White, January 18, 1923

div1.p: Avila describes a possible yellow fever case in Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from Manuel Avila to Joseph H. White, January 18, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B
Mexico
COPY
T R A N S L A T I O N
#118
Dr. Joseph H. White, Director,
Comision Espedial contra la Fiebre Amarilla,
Tampico, Tamps.
div1.p:
I have the honor of placing in your superior knowledge that
the case considered as suspicious of Yellow Fever, and of which I wired
you on the 17th of this month, appears to be confirmed, as you will see
by perusal of the following.

José Rios, 26 years old, native of León, Guanajuato, single,
carpenter. Last employed as Fumigation Agent in Tampico and Panuco
during part of 1922. Since has worked as Watchman for the Freeport Oil
Co. at Well #6, Reventadero, Cacalilao.

Patient first became sick on the 8th of this month, complain-
ing of chills in the afternoons, the fever disappearing towards morning.
He became cured by the usual quininization. On the 15th he became very
sick, severe chill, high fever, headache, pain in the legs, etc. As
patient was troubled by nausea and vomiting he came to Panuco on the 16th
and was seen by me the following day. On examination the following was
noted: Flushed face, eyes bloodshot and jaundiced pupils slightly dilated,
temp. 40.5 c. pulse and respiration rapid. Pain in Epigastrium, intense
thirst. Tongue white and coated in the middle, edges red, constipation,
nausea and vomiting, general jaundice, urine scarse and albuminous and
stained with bile. Examination on the next day (18th) further showed.
Temp. 39.6c., vomiting less but now “coffee ground” in appearance, jaundice
very marked. Nose bleed and bloody sputum, tongue covered with dark bloody
film. Urine scanty and albuminous, stools black with altered blood. Pulse
weak and rapid, respiration slightly increased. Liver large and tender.
Spleen slightly enlarged. Other organs normal. General condition good.

For these reasons, I believe that José Rios has suffered a slight
attack of Yellow Fever, probably contracted in Cacalilao, where he had last
lived and where Yellow Fever has claimed other victims.
Antilarvae and Fumigation work proceeds in Cacalilao and Reventadero.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, (Signed) Dr. Manuel Avila,
Delegado Sanitario Especial,
Panuco, Veracruz, January 18, 1923. Translated by H. B. R.
